#Text=Mirza Ghiyas Beg
#Text=Warning :
#Text=Page using Template : Infobox officeholder with unknown parameter " religion " ( this message is shown only in preview ) .

#Text=Mirza Ghiyas Beg ( Urdu : مرزا غياث بيگ ) , also known by his title of I'timad-ud-Daulah ( Persian : اعتمادالسلطنه آگهی الدوله‎ ) , was an important Persian official in the Mughal empire , whose children served as wives , mothers , and generals of the Mughal emperors .
#Text=Born in Tehran , Ghiyas Beg belonged to a family of poets and high officials .
#Text=Nevertheless , his fortunes fell into disfavor after the death of his father in 1576 .
#Text=Along with his pregnant wife Asmat Begum , and his three children , they immigrated to India .
#Text=There he was received by the Mughal emperor Akbar ( r. 1556-1605 ) , and was enrolled into his service .
#Text=During the latters reign , Ghiyas Beg was appointed treasurer for the province of Kabul .

#Text=His fortunes further increased during the reign of Akbar 's son and successor Jahangir ( r. 1605-1627 ) , who in 1611 married his daughter Nur Jahan and appointed Ghiyas Beg as his Prime minister .
#Text=By 1615 , Ghiyas Beg had risen to further prominence , when he was given the status of 6,000 men and was given a standard and drums , a prestige normally restricted for distinguished princes .
#Text=Family

#Text=Ghiyas Beg was a native of Tehran , and was the youngest son of Khvajeh Mohammad-Sharif , a poet and vizier of Mohammad Khan Tekkelu and his son Tatar Soltan , who was the governor of the Safavid province of Khorasan .
#Text=Mohammad-Sharif was later listed under the service of Shah Tahmasp I ( r. 1524 – 1576 ) , where he in the start served as the vizier of Yazd , Abarkuh , and Biabanak for seven years .
#Text=Thereafter he was appointed as the vizier of Isfahan , and died there in 1576 . [ 1 ]
#Text=Ghiyas Beg 's elder brother , Mohammad-Taher Wasli , was a learned man who composed poetry under the pen name of Wasli . [ 2 ]
#Text=Immigration to India
#Text=After the death of Ghiyas ' father , his family fell into disgrace .

#Text=Hoping to improve his family ’s fortunes , Ghiyas Beg chose to relocate to India where the Emperor Akbar 's court was said to be at the centre of the growing trade industry and cultural scene . [ 3 ]
#Text=Half way along their route the family was attacked by robbers who took from them the remaining meager possessions they had . [ 4 ]

#Text=Left with only two mules , Ghiyas Beg , his pregnant wife , and their three children ( Mohammad-Sharif , Asaf Khan and a daughter Sahlia ) were forced to take turns riding on the backs of the animals for the remained of their journey .
#Text=When the family arrived in Kandahar , Asmat Begam gave birth to their second daughter .
#Text=The family was so impoverished they feared they would be unable to take care of the newborn baby .
#Text=Fortunately , the family was taken in by a caravan led by the merchant noble Malik Masud , who would later assist Ghiyas Beg in finding a job in the service of Emperor Akbar .
#Text=Believing that the child had signaled a change in the family ’s fate , she was named Mehrunnisa , meaning " sun among women " . [ 5 ]

#Text=Ghiyas Beg was the not the first member of his family to move to India — his cousin Asaf Khan Jafar Beg and the uncle of Asmat Begum , Mirza Ghiyasuddin Ali Asaf Khan , had been enrolled into the provincial assignments of Akbar . [ 6 ]
#Text=Service under the Mughal Empire
#Text=Ghiyas was later appointed diwan ( treasurer ) for the province of Kabul .
#Text=Due to his astute skills at conducting business he quickly rose through the ranks of the high administrative officials .
#Text=For his excellent work he was awarded the title of ‘ ‘ Itimad-ud-Daula ‘ ‘ ( ‘ Pillar of the State ’ ) by the emperor . [ 4 ]
#Text=As a result of his work and promotions , Ghiyas Beg was able to ensure that Mehirunnisa ( the future Nur Jahan ) would have the best possible education .
#Text=She became well versed in Arabic and Persian .
#Text=She also became well versed in art , literature , music and dance . [ 5 ]
#Text=Mirza Ghiyas Beg 's tomb in Agra
#Text=Ghiyas ' daughter , Mehrunissa ( Nur Jahan ) married Akbar 's son Jahangir in 1611 , and his son Abdul Hasan Asaf Khan served as a general to Jahangir .

#Text=Ghiyas was also the grandfather of Mumtaz Mahal ( originally named Arjumand Bano , daughter of Abdul Hasan Asaf Khan ) , the wife of the emperor Shah Jahan , responsible for the building of the Taj Mahal .
#Text=Jahangir was succeeded by his son Shah Jahan , and Abdul Hasan served as one of Shah Jahan 's closest advisors .
#Text=Shah Jahan married
#Text=Abdul Hasan 's daughter Arjumand Banu Begum , Mumtāz Mahal , who was the mother of his four sons , including his successor Aurangzeb .
#Text=Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal to serve as Mumtaz Mahal 's tomb .
#Text=Death and burial
#Text=Ghiyas Beg died near Kangra in 1622 while the Mughal camp was moving towards its summer residence in Kashmir .
#Text=His body was carried back to Agra , where he was buried on the right bank of the Yamuna river .
#Text=His burial place still stands till this day , and is known as Tomb of I'timad-ud-Daulah .
